title: 104_s1206
content: The "Adoption Assistance Act" is cited as the short title. It introduces a refundable credit for adoption expenses under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Adoption Assistance Act introduces a credit for qualified adoption expenses paid by individuals, limited to $5,000 per child. The credit amount is reduced based on the taxpayer's income. The tax code specifies that the adoption credit is limited based on the taxpayer's adjusted gross income, with no double benefits allowed for expenses covered by other provisions. Additionally, no credit is allowed for expenses covered by federal, state, or local programs. The tax code limits the adoption credit based on the taxpayer's income and does not allow double benefits or credit for expenses covered by other programs. Qualified adoption expenses include fees directly related to legal adoption, excluding expenses for adopting a spouse's child. Qualified adoption expenses exclude expenses for adopting a spouse's child. Conforming amendments are made to certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code. Title II of the document focuses on adoption assistance for federal employees, specifically reimbursement for adoption expenses. The amendments made in this section apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995. The program allows reimbursement for adoption expenses incurred by employees, including fees charged by adoption agencies, legal fees, medical expenses, and transportation expenses. Employees can be reimbursed for adoption expenses incurred in adopting a child under certain conditions, including the child being under 18 years of age and unmarried at the time of finalization. Written application with required information must be submitted within the specified timeframe. Reimbursement is contingent on similar benefits not being paid under other programs. Employees can be reimbursed for adoption expenses under certain conditions, with a maximum limit of $2,000 per parent if other benefits do not cover the full amount. If both parents are eligible, each can receive reimbursement, but the total amount cannot exceed a certain limit. The guidelines for reimbursement of adoption expenses include a maximum limit of $4,000, to be paid from the appropriate fund. Applications cannot be denied based on marital status, and general guidelines are issued by the Office of Personnel Management for uniform administration. The Office issues guidelines for uniform administration of regulations under this section. Executive agencies must comply with these guidelines. The Office can provide assistance upon request. Conforming amendments are made to the heading of subpart G of title 5, United States Code. The analysis for part III of title 5, United States Code, is amended to include "SUBPART G--ANNUITIES, INSURANCE, AND MISCELLANEOUS BENEFITS" and a new item "90. Miscellaneous Employee Benefits" is added. Section 1005 of title 39, United States Code, is amended to apply Section 9001 of title 5 to the Postal Service. Regulations must be consistent with guidelines issued under subsection (g)(1) of such section. The title will be effective on October 1, 1995, applying to adoptions finalized on or after that date. Title III excludes adoption assistance under section 137 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Employee adoption assistance benefits and military adoption assistance benefits received by an employee for adopting a child are not included in the employee's gross income. Employee adoption assistance benefits refer to payments by an employer for qualified adoption expenses, while military adoption assistance benefits are benefits provided to military personnel for adoption. The term 'military adoption assistance benefits' refers to benefits provided under specific sections of the United States Code for military personnel. 'Qualified adoption expenses' include fees directly related to legal adoption of an eligible child by the taxpayer, excluding expenses incurred in violation of State or Federal law or in surrogate parenting arrangements. The term 'eligible child' refers to an individual under 18 or incapable of self-care. The Secretary will coordinate this section with other provisions allowing adoption expense credits or deductions. The amendments made in this section regarding adoption assistance will apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 1995.
